poem:
Title: In Praise of Starlings

Among the undulating green,
starlings form an aria.
Chattering like cogs unseen,
marking days in their gardenia.
They chequer trees with dotted song,
black notes against the dawn, fluttering long.
In labor or in still ponder,
under the Brighton pier they wander. 
Murmurations make a seaside sonnet,
my shed, my seeds, starlings on it.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Country diary: For the starlings, this is a tale of two cities | Kate Bradbury On the allotment, the trees sing with starlings, as if the birds were decorating them, as if it were Christmas. I listen to them click and whistle as I clear a bed to sow seeds. They chatter while I repaint my shed. They’re famous for murmurating around Brighton pier, said to be one of the best places in the country to watch". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: Country diary: For the starlings, this is a tale of two cities | Kate Bradbury On the allotment, the trees sing with starlings, as if the birds were decorating them, as if it were Christmas. I listen to them click and whistle as I clear a bed to sow seeds. They chatter while I repaint my shed. They’re famous for murmurating around Brighton pier, said to be one of the best places in the country to watch
